results.question: Is a party restricted from contracting or soliciting customers or partners of the counterparty, whether during the contract or after the contract ends (or both)?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yes, the franchise agreement contains restrictions on the franchisee's ability to compete with Pretzel Time, both during the term of the franchise agreement and after its termination or expiration.

Specifically:

1. During the term of the franchise agreement, the franchisee agrees that neither it, its affiliates, nor its owners will have any direct or indirect interest in a "Competitive Business" located at the franchise site, within 3 miles of the franchise unit, or within 3 miles of any other Pretzel Time unit in operation or under development (Section 21.A).

2. After termination or expiration of the franchise agreement, the franchisee and its owners agree not to have any direct or indirect interest in a Competitive Business located at the franchise site, within 3 miles of the franchise unit, or within 3 miles of any other Pretzel Time unit in operation or under development for a period of 12 months (Section 20.G).

The agreement also restricts the franchisee from recruiting or hiring any employees who were employed by Pretzel Time or another Pretzel Time franchisee within the prior 6 months, without Pretzel Time's prior written permission (Section 21.A(2)).

So in summary, the franchise agreement imposes non-compete and non-solicitation restrictions on the franchisee both during the contract term and for a period after the contract ends.
results.generated_response:
Yes.  
During the term of the Franchise Agreement (and for so long as the Franchisee operates a Unit), the Franchisee and its affiliates/family members are barred from having any interest in, or performing services for, a “Competitive Business” located within three miles of any Pretzel Time Unit (§1). In addition, for six months after an employee leaves Pretzel Time or any Pretzel Time Unit, the Franchisee may not recruit or hire that employee without Pretzel Time’s prior written consent (§2). These clauses restrict both competition for customers and solicitation of personnel while the agreement is in force and for a limited period post-termination.

results.question: Does one party have the right to terminate or is consent or notice required of the counterparty if such party undergoes a change of control, such as a merger, stock sale, transfer of all or substantially all of its assets or business, or assignment by operation of law?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yes, the agreement provides that one party (About) has the right to terminate the agreement immediately upon written notice if the other party (ebix) becomes acquired by, merged into or is under the control of certain specified parties, including AOL, Yahoo, Lycos/Terra, NBC, CBS, and others.

Specifically, Section 13.3 states:

"Either party may terminate immediately upon written notice if the other party (i) ceases to function as a going concern or to conduct operations in the normal course of business; (ii) has a petition filed against it under any state or federal bankruptcy law which petition has not been dismissed or set aside within ninety (90) days of its filing, or if (a) About sells all or substantially all of the assets of such party or any event or series of event whereby any entity acquires beneficial ownership of the capital stock of such party representing fifty percent (50%) of the voting stock of such party provided however, that the acquisition of About by Primedia shall not be grounds for the termination of this Agreement; or (b) ebix becomes acquired by, merged into or is under the control of any of the following parties, About may terminate this Agreement immediately upon by providing ebix written notice: AOL; Yahoo; Lycos/Terra; NBC; CBS; Looksmart; InfoSpace; CMGI; AltaVista; Disney; Microsoft; CNET; Excite@Home; AskJeeves; GOTO; Doubleclick; or Lifeminders."

So About has the unilateral right to terminate the agreement if ebix undergoes a change of control by being acquired by or merged with any of the specified entities, without requiring consent or notice from ebix.
results.generated_response:
Yes.  
If eBix is acquired by, merged into, or comes under the control of any of the listed companies (AOL, Yahoo, Lycos/Terra, NBC, CBS, Looksmart, InfoSpace, CMGI, AltaVista, Disney, Microsoft, CNET, Excite@Home, AskJeeves, GOTO, Doubleclick, or Lifeminders), About may terminate the Agreement immediately upon written notice—no consent from eBix is required.

Conversely, if About sells all or substantially all of its assets or undergoes any transaction whereby an entity acquires 50 % of its voting stock (other than the specifically-permitted acquisition of About by Primedia), either party may terminate on written notice; again, no counter-party consent is needed.

Based on the information provided in the software development agreement, the notice period required to terminate the agreement without cause is two weeks. 

Specifically, Section 11.1 states:

"Either Party may terminate this Agreement at any time during the term of this Agreement for any reason upon two weeks written notice to the other Party."

So the agreement can be terminated without cause by either party with two weeks' written notice.
results.generated_response: The notice period required to terminate the agreement (including renewals) without cause is **two weeks written notice**.

results.question: What is the renewal term after the initial term expires? This includes automatic extensions and unilateral extensions with prior notice.
results.ground_truth_answer:
The agreement does not specify a renewal term or any provisions for automatic extensions or unilateral extensions with prior notice after the initial term expires. The initial term is described in Section 2, which states that the appointment of the Agent shall terminate upon the earlier to occur of:

(a) forty-five (45) days after the last day of the Subscription and Community Offering, unless the Company and the Agent agree in writing to extend such period and the OTS agrees to extend the period of time in which the Securities may be sold, 
(b) the receipt and acceptance of subscriptions and purchase orders for all of the Securities, or
(c) the completion of the Syndicated Community Offering.

There is no mention of a renewal term or any provisions for extending the agreement beyond this initial term.

results.question: Does one party have the right to terminate or is consent or notice required of the counterparty if such party undergoes a change of control, such as a merger, stock sale, transfer of all or substantially all of its assets or business, or assignment by operation of law?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the information provided in the sponsorship agreement, there does not appear to be any explicit provision that allows one party to unilaterally terminate the agreement in the event of a change of control of the other party, such as a merger, stock sale, transfer of assets, or assignment by operation of law.

The agreement states that it "shall bind the parties, their respective heirs, personal representatives, successors and assigns." This suggests that the agreement is intended to remain in effect even if there is a change in ownership or control of one of the parties.

Additionally, the agreement states that "This Agreement, or the rights granted under it, may not be assigned transferred or sublicense by either party without the express prior written consent of the other party." This indicates that any assignment or transfer of the agreement would require the consent of the other party.

Therefore, based on the information provided, it does not appear that one party has the unilateral right to terminate the agreement due to a change of control of the other party. Consent or notice to the counterparty would likely be required for any such change.
results.generated_response: No. The Agreement does not contain any provision that gives a party a termination right or requires the other party’s consent or notice merely because a change of control (merger, stock sale, asset transfer, or assignment by operation of law) occurs.

results.question: Is there a non-contracting party who is a beneficiary to some or all of the clauses in the contract and therefore can enforce its rights against a contracting party?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yes, based on the information provided in the contract, there is a non-contracting party that is a beneficiary to some of the clauses and can therefore enforce its rights against a contracting party.

Specifically, the contract mentions "Replacement Supplier" in several clauses, such as Clauses 17, 18, 19, and 20. These clauses indicate that the Replacement Supplier, even though not an original contracting party, will have certain rights and obligations relevant to the termination of the agreement and the transfer of the maintenance services.

For example, Clause 18.2 states that "DCL shall procure the transfer of the Management Services either from SEV to DCL or from SEV to any Replacement Supplier." This suggests that the Replacement Supplier can enforce its right to have the maintenance services transferred to it upon termination of the agreement.

Additionally, Clause 20 outlines the rights and obligations of DCL, SEV, and the Replacement Supplier in the event that the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations apply to the termination of the agreement. This further indicates that the Replacement Supplier has enforceable rights under the contract.

Therefore, based on the provisions in the contract, the Replacement Supplier appears to be a non-contracting party that can nonetheless enforce certain rights against the contracting parties, SEV and DCL.

results.question: Does intellectual property created  by one party become the property of the counterparty, either per the terms of the contract or upon the occurrence of certain events?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the content license agreement, the intellectual property rights to the Titles do not become the property of the counterparty (Licensee). The key points are:

1. Licensor grants Licensee a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the Titles, but Licensor retains ownership of the Titles (Section 2(a)).

2. Licensee is not granted any ownership rights in the Titles or the Licensor Marks (the logos, trademarks and service marks used to identify the Titles). Licensor only grants Licensee a non-exclusive license to use the Licensor Marks in connection with the Titles (Section 11).

3. There is no provision in the agreement that states the intellectual property rights to the Titles will transfer to the Licensee upon the occurrence of certain events. 

4. The agreement states that Sections 2(a), 2(b), 2(c), 2(d), 3, and 11 shall survive the expiration or termination of the agreement (Section 7(c)). This indicates the Licensor retains ownership of the intellectual property rights even after the agreement ends.

So in summary, the intellectual property rights to the Titles remain the property of the Licensor throughout the term of the agreement and beyond, and do not become the property of the Licensee under the terms of this contract.

results.question: Is a party’s liability uncapped upon the breach of its obligation in the contract? This also includes uncap liability for a particular type of breach such as IP infringement or breach of confidentiality obligation.
results.ground_truth_answer:
No, the party's liability is not uncapped upon breach of the contract. The agreement contains specific limitations on liability:

1. Section 10.4(a) limits the aggregate liability of each party in any 12-month period to 1.5 times the aggregate amounts paid or payable by Customer to Manufacturer during the preceding 12-month period, solely with respect to the affected products for which the liability arose.

2. Section 10.4(b) specifically provides that neither party shall be liable for consequential, special, incidental or indirect damages, lost revenue or profits, etc., except in certain enumerated cases, such as a breach of the confidentiality obligations under Section 13.

So the agreement does not provide for uncapped liability upon breach. The liability is limited in the ways specified in Section 10.4.

The only exceptions are for certain types of breaches, such as:

- Breaches of the confidentiality obligations under Section 13
- Gross negligence, fraud or willful misconduct of a party
- Willful breach of the agreement
- Indemnification obligations under Sections 10.1 and 10.2 for third-party claims

In these cases, the limitations on liability in Section 10.4 do not apply. But otherwise, the parties' liability is subject to the caps and limitations outlined in Section 10.4.

results.question: Does the contract include a cap on liability upon the breach of a party’s obligation? This includes time limitation for the counterparty to bring claims or maximum amount for recovery.
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yes, the contract includes provisions that limit liability upon breach of a party's obligations:

1. Limitation of Liability: Section 12.2 states that "IN NO EVENT WILL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE FOR ANY INDIRECT, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL, EXEMPLARY, PUNITIVE OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES OF ANY KIND, INCLUDING ANY LOST PROFITS, LOST REVENUES OR LOST SAVINGS, ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THIS AGREEMENT AND/OR THE PRODUCTS, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, TORT, STRICT LIABILITY OR OTHERWISE, EVEN IF THE PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED, KNOWS OR SHOULD KNOW, OR IS OTHERWISE AWARE OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES." This caps the liability to direct damages only.

2. Time Limitation to Bring Claims: The contract does not explicitly state a time limitation for bringing claims. However, Section 14.3 states that if a party defaults or breaches the agreement, the non-defaulting party must give written notice and the defaulting party has 15 days to cure the breach before the agreement can be terminated. This suggests the parties have at least 15 days to bring a claim for breach before the agreement can be terminated.

3. Maximum Recovery Amount: The contract does not specify a maximum recovery amount for damages. It only limits the types of damages that can be recovered (i.e. no indirect, special, incidental, etc. damages).

In summary, the contract includes a limitation on liability for certain types of damages, but does not explicitly state a time limitation for bringing claims or a maximum recovery amount.

results.question: Is a party subject to obligations after the termination or expiration of a contract, including any post-termination transition, payment, transfer of IP, wind-down, last-buy, or similar commitments?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the consulting agreement provided, there are several provisions that indicate the parties do have certain obligations that survive the termination or expiration of the agreement:

1. Section 8.2 states that the obligations of Sections 3, 5, 6 and 7 shall survive any termination of the agreement. These sections cover key provisions such as:
   - Independent contractor relationship (Section 3)
   - Confidentiality and non-disclosure of proprietary information (Section 5) 
   - Ownership of intellectual property and work product (Section 6)
   - Restrictive covenants like non-solicitation and non-competition (Section 7)

2. Section 8.1 requires the consultant to promptly return all materials, property, documents, data, and other information belonging to the company upon termination.

3. Section 9.7 on indemnification provides obligations that survive termination for a period of 3 years.

4. The Statement of Work indicates the initial 12-month term will automatically renew for an additional 12 months unless the agreement is terminated, suggesting ongoing obligations during any renewal period.

So in summary, yes, the agreement demonstrates that the parties have certain post-termination obligations, particularly around confidentiality, intellectual property, restrictive covenants, and indemnification. The agreement is structured to have key provisions survive beyond the termination or expiration of the overall consulting relationship.

results.question: Is consent or notice required of a party if the contract is assigned to a third party?

So Rogers can assign the contract without consent to (i) an affiliate company or (ii) a purchaser of the assets used for the ROD service. 

For any other assignment, Section 24 states "This Agreement may not be assigned, sold or transferred without the prior written consent of the other party."

Therefore, in general, consent or notice is required from the other party (Licensor) if the contract is assigned to a third party, with the exceptions noted above for certain assignments by Rogers.

results.question: Can a party terminate this  contract without cause (solely by giving a notice and allowing a waiting  period to expire)?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the terms of the agreement, it does not appear that either party can terminate the contract without cause solely by giving notice and allowing a waiting period to expire.

The termination provisions are outlined in Section 14.2 of the agreement. This section lists the specific conditions under which either party can terminate the agreement, and they all require some form of material breach, insolvency, or other substantive reason for termination.

Specifically:

- Section 14.2(a) allows either party to terminate immediately upon written notice in the event the other party becomes insolvent, files for bankruptcy, admits inability to pay debts, etc.

- Section 14.2(a) also allows either party to terminate immediately upon written notice if the other party fails to cure a default within 30 days after written notice.

- Section 14.2(b) allows Licensor to terminate with 90 days' prior written notice if Licensee does not meet certain revenue targets (the "Quota Amount").

- Section 14.2(b) also allows Licensor to terminate with 30 days' prior written notice if Licensee undergoes a change of control event.

There is no provision that would allow either party to simply terminate the agreement without cause by giving notice and allowing a waiting period to expire. The termination rights are limited to the specific circumstances outlined in Section 14.2.

Supplier shall inform all of its personnel providing services pursuant to this Agreement that they will not be considered employees of Bank of America for any purpose, and that Bank of America shall not be liable to any of them as an employer for any claims or causes of action arising out of or relating to their assignment. 25.3 Upon the request of Bank of America, Supplier shall immediately remove any of Supplier's Representatives or Subcontractors performing services under this Agreement and replace such Representative or Subcontractor as soon as practicable. Upon the request of Bank of America, Supplier shall promptly, and after consultation with Bank of America, address any concerns or issues raised by Bank of America regarding any of Supplier's Representatives or Subcontractors performing services under this Agreement which may include, as appropriate, replacing such Representative or Subcontractor from the Bank of America account. 25.4 The engagement of a Subcontractor by Supplier shall be subject to Bank of America's prior written consent, which shall not be unreasonably withheld, and shall not relieve Supplier of any of its obligations under this Agreement. Supplier shall be responsible for the performance or nonperformance of its Subcontractors as if such performance or nonperformance were that of Supplier. Supplier shall require all Subcontractors, as a condition to their engagement, to agree to be bound by provisions substantially the same as those included in this Agreement particularly the Sections entitled "Supplier Personnel," "Insurance," "Confidentiality and Information Protection," "Audit" and "Business Continuity."

25.5 Supplier shall comply and shall cause its Representatives and Subcontractors to comply with all personnel, facility, safety and security policies, rules and regulations and other instructions of Bank of America, when performing work at a Bank of America facility or accessing any Bank of America systems or data, and shall conduct its work at Bank of America facilities or on Bank of America systems in such a manner as to avoid endangering the safety, or interfering with the convenience of, Bank of America Representatives or customers. Supplier understands that Bank of America operates under various laws and regulations that are unique to the security-sensitive banking industry.

As such, persons engaged by Supplier to provide services under this Agreement are held to a higher standard of conduct and scrutiny than in other industries or business enterprises. Supplier agrees that its Representatives and Subcontractors providing services hereunder shall possess appropriate character, disposition and honesty. Supplier shall, to the extent permitted by law, exercise reasonable and prudent efforts to comply with the security provisions of this Agreement.

25.6 Supplier shall not knowingly permit a Representative or Subcontractor to have access to the Confidential Information, premises, records or data of Bank of America when such Representative or Subcontractor: (a) has been convicted of a crime or has agreed to or entered into a pretrial diversion or similar program in connection with: (i) a dishonest act or a breach of trust, as set forth in Section 19 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, 12 U.S.C.

5.8 In the event of expiration or termination of this Agreement, an Order or of Maintenance Services under this Agreement, Supplier agrees that upon the request of Bank of America, Supplier will, at no additional cost to Bank of America and through the period of paid up Maintenance Services, continue uninterrupted operations, conclude and cooperate with Bank of America in the transition of the business at Bank of America's direction and in a manner that causes no material disruption to Bank of America business and operations. The fees associated with such transition shall be in accordance with the fees in effect at the expiration or termination of this Agreement. In no event shall the transition exceed one hundred eighty [180] calendar days from the date of termination unless the Parties otherwise agree in writing.
